UI_visible_response: The May Fourth Movement, which erupted on May 4th, 1919, stood as a seminal event in Chinese history, marking a national campaign against foreign imperialism1. It was directed toward national independence, emancipation of the individual, and rebuilding society and culture4. One of the slogans of the movement was a call for 'Mr. Democracy' and 'Mr. Science,' meaning for democracy and science2. The movement also aimed to promote new cultural values and reform traditional Chinese society3. Additionally, it involved student protests and demonstrated strong nationalism, as seen when more than 3,000 students from 13 colleges in Beijing held a mass demonstration against the decision of the Versailles Peace Conference6. Overall, the ambitious goals included national independence, personal freedom, and societal and cultural reconstruction5.
traffic_visible_response: The May Fourth Movement, which erupted on May 4th, 1919, stood as a seminal event in Chinese history, marking a national campaign against foreign imperialism [[1]]. It was directed toward national independence, emancipation of the individual, and rebuilding society and culture [[4]]. One of the slogans of the movement was a call for 'Mr. Democracy' and 'Mr. Science,' meaning for democracy and science [[2]]. The movement also aimed to promote new cultural values and reform traditional Chinese society [[3]]. Additionally, it involved student protests and demonstrated strong nationalism, as seen when more than 3,000 students from 13 colleges in Beijing held a mass demonstration against the decision of the Versailles Peace Conference [[6]]. Overall, the ambitious goals included national independence, personal freedom, and societal and cultural reconstruction [[5]].
